<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 322, 390, 336]]<|/det|>
# READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 352, 828, 367]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 368, 722, 383]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 327, 399]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 400, 497, 415]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 601, 431]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 448, 285, 462]]<|/det|>
Answer **all** the questions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 463, 907, 493]]<|/det|>
Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 494, 720, 510]]<|/det|>
Where a numerical value for the acceleration due to gravity is needed, use \(10 \text{m s}^{-2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 510, 590, 525]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 526, 606, 541]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 558, 606, 572]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 573, 757, 588]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 590, 440, 604]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 50.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 605, 907, 635]]<|/det|>
Questions carrying smaller numbers of marks are printed earlier in the paper, and questions carrying larger numbers of marks later in the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
A block is at rest on a rough horizontal plane. The coefficient of friction between the block and the plane is 1.25.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 120, 156, 139]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 120, 920, 154]]<|/det|>
State, giving a reason for your answer, whether the minimum vertical force required to move the block is greater or less than the minimum horizontal force required to move the block. [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 166, 920, 201]]<|/det|>
A horizontal force of continuously increasing magnitude \(P \mathrm{N}\) and fixed direction is applied to the block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 214, 153, 231]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 212, 920, 247]]<|/det|>
Given that the weight of the block is \(60 \mathrm{N}\), find the value of \(P\) when the acceleration of the block is \(4 \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{-2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 231, 920, 248]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 276, 94, 294]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 275, 920, 342]]<|/det|>
A car of mass \(1250\mathrm{kg}\) travels from the bottom to the top of a straight hill of length \(600\mathrm{m}\), which is inclined at an angle of \(2.5^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. The resistance to motion of the car is constant and equal to \(400\mathrm{N}.\) The work done by the driving force is \(450\mathrm{kJ}.\) The speed of the car at the bottom of the hill is \(30\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{-1}\) . Find the speed of the car at the top of the hill.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 327, 920, 344]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 370, 94, 388]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 369, 920, 404]]<|/det|>
The top of a cliff is 40 metres above the level of the sea. A man in a boat, close to the bottom of the cliff, is in difficulty and fires a distress signal vertically upwards from sea level. Find

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 411, 153, 429]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 411, 920, 444]]<|/det|>
the speed of projection of the signal given that it reaches a height of \(5 \mathrm{m}\) above the top of the cliff,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 435, 920, 453]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 451, 148, 469]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 451, 781, 470]]<|/det|>
the length of time for which the signal is above the level of the top of the cliff.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 452, 920, 470]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 483, 920, 516]]<|/det|>
The man fires another distress signal vertically upwards from sea level. This signal is above the level of the top of the cliff for \(\sqrt{(} 17)\) s.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 529, 146, 547]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 528, 552, 547]]<|/det|>
Find the speed of projection of the second signal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 528, 920, 547]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 574, 92, 593]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 574, 920, 607]]<|/det|>
A train of mass \(400 000\mathrm{kg}\) is moving on a straight horizontal track. The power of the engine is constant and equal to \(1500\mathrm{kW}\) and the resistance to the train's motion is \(30 000\mathrm{N}\). Find

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 617, 153, 635]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 616, 608, 635]]<|/det|>
the acceleration of the train when its speed is \(37.5 \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{-1}\),

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 616, 920, 635]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 642, 153, 660]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 642, 520, 660]]<|/det|>
the steady speed at which the train can move.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 641, 920, 660]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[354, 81, 680, 180]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 198, 920, 297]]<|/det|>
A light inextensible string has a particle \(A\) of mass \(0.26\mathrm{kg}\) attached to one end and a particle \(B\) of mass \(0.54\mathrm{kg}\) attached to the other end. The particle \(A\) is held at rest on a rough plane inclined at angle \(\alpha\) to the horizontal, where \(\sin \alpha = \frac{5}{13}\). The string is taut and parallel to a line of greatest slope of the plane. The string passes over a small smooth pulley at the top of the plane. Particle \(B\) hangs at rest vertically below the pulley (see diagram). The coefficient of friction between \(A\) and the plane is 0.2. Particle \(A\) is released and the particles start to move.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 310, 153, 327]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 310, 821, 329]]<|/det|>
Find the magnitude of the acceleration of the particles and the tension in the string.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 310, 918, 327]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 339, 569, 358]]<|/det|>
Particle \(A\) reaches the pulley \(0.4 \mathrm{~s}\) after starting to move.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 370, 153, 388]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 370, 551, 388]]<|/det|>
Find the distance moved by each of the particles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 370, 920, 388]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 416, 96, 435]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[285, 428, 749, 648]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 668, 920, 700]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) of mass \(0.5 \mathrm{~kg}\) lies on a smooth horizontal plane. Horizontal forces of magnitudes \(F \mathrm{~N}\), \(2.5 \mathrm{~N}\) and \(2.6 \mathrm{~N}\) act on \(P\). The directions of the forces are as shown in the diagram, where \(\tan \alpha = \frac{12}{5}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 702, 238, 721]]<|/det|>
and \(\tan \beta = \frac{7}{24}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 734, 153, 752]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 734, 645, 752]]<|/det|>
Given that \(P\) is in equilibrium, find the values of \(F\) and \(\tan \theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 734, 918, 752]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 765, 153, 782]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 764, 920, 798]]<|/det|>
The force of magnitude \(F \mathrm{~N}\) is removed. Find the magnitude and direction of the acceleration with which \(P\) starts to move.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 782, 918, 798]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[327, 852, 670, 871]]<|/det|>
[Question 7 is printed on the next page.]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
A car driver makes a journey in a straight line from \(A\) to \(B\), starting from rest. The speed of the car increases to a maximum, then decreases until the car is at rest at \(B\). The distance travelled by the car \(t\) seconds after leaving \(A\) is \(0.0000117(400t^3 - 3t^4)\) metres.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 136, 151, 154]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 136, 331, 154]]<|/det|>
Find the distance \(AB\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 136, 920, 154]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 166, 153, 184]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 166, 447, 184]]<|/det|>
Find the maximum speed of the car.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 166, 920, 184]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 198, 153, 215]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 198, 410, 215]]<|/det|>
Find the acceleration of the car

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 224, 346, 242]]<|/det|>
(a) as it starts from \(A\),

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 250, 331, 266]]<|/det|>
(b) as it arrives at \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 266, 920, 284]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 293, 151, 311]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 293, 532, 311]]<|/det|>
Sketch the velocity-time graph for the journey.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 293, 920, 311]]<|/det|>
